unnormalised: Alright, so geometry and trig, huh? Sounds scary, but trust me, it’s not *that* bad. Think of it as puzzles with numbers and shapes – like a Sudoku, but with angles and lines. Remember those compasses and protractors from school? Yeah, those things. Turns out they weren’t just for torturing us!
normalised: Alright, so geometry and trig, huh? Sounds scary, but trust me, it’s not that bad. Think of it as puzzles with numbers and shapes – like a Sudoku, but with angles and lines. Remember those compasses and protractors from school? Yeah, those things. Turns out they weren’t just for torturing us!

unnormalised: Let’s start with the basics. You’ve got your points, lines, planes – the building blocks. Then comes the fun stuff: triangles! Right-angled, equilateral, isosceles… they're all like the Bollywood stars of geometry. Each one has its own drama and special properties. Pythagoras Theorem (a² + b² = c²) is the hero of the right-angled triangle story. Seriously, memorize it. You'll need it.
normalised: Let’s start with the basics. You’ve got your points, lines, planes – the building blocks. Then comes the fun stuff: triangles! Right-angled, equilateral, isosceles… they're all like the B-O-L-L-Y-W-O-O-D stars of geometry. Each one has its own drama and special properties. Pythagoras Theorem (a squared plus b squared equals c squared) is the hero of the right-angled triangle story. Seriously, memorize it. You'll need it.

unnormalised: Then there are circles. πr², 2πr – these are your mantras. Remember, π is approximately 3.14 (or 22/7 if you're feeling old-school). Circles are everywhere, from the wheels of your auto-rickshaw to the samosa on your plate (okay, maybe the samosa isn't a perfect circle, but work with me!).
normalised: Then there are circles. pi r squared, two pi r – these are your mantras. Remember, pi is approximately three point one four (or twenty two divided by seven if you're feeling old-school). Circles are everywhere, from the wheels of your auto-rickshaw to the samosa on your plate (okay, maybe the samosa isn't a perfect circle, but work with me!).

unnormalised: Now, onto trigonometry. This is where things get a *little* more complicated, but don't sweat it. Sine, cosine, tangent – these are just ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle. SOH CAH TOA (Some Old Horses Catch Another Horse Taking Oats Away) is the trick my tuition teacher, Mr. Sharma, used to make us remember. And it works!
normalised: Now, onto trigonometry. This is where things get a little more complicated, but don't sweat it. Sine, cosine, tangent – these are just ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle. S-O-H C-A-H T-O-A (Some Old Horses Catch Another Horse Taking Oats Away) is the trick my tuition teacher, Mister Sharma, used to make us remember. And it works!

unnormalised: Think about it this way: sine is opposite over hypotenuse (SOH), cosine is adjacent over hypotenuse (CAH), and tangent is opposite over adjacent (TOA). You can use these to find angles or sides if you know enough information. Imagine climbing the Qutub Minar and needing to find its height by just knowing the angle of elevation at a certain distance. That's where trig comes in clutch.
normalised: Think about it this way: sine is opposite over hypotenuse (S-O-H), cosine is adjacent over hypotenuse (C-A-H), and tangent is opposite over adjacent (T-O-A). You can use these to find angles or sides if you know enough information. Imagine climbing the Qutub Minar and needing to find its height by just knowing the angle of elevation at a certain distance. That's where trig comes in clutch.

unnormalised: Honestly, mastering this stuff is less about memorizing formulas and more about understanding the relationships between things. Visualizing the problem makes a huge difference. Try drawing diagrams, labelling everything, and breaking down complex shapes into simpler ones. Geometry box is your friend here, not foe!

unnormalised: Real-world applications? Tons! Architecture uses geometry and trig to design buildings, bridges and layouts. Navigation systems use trig to calculate distances and directions. Even video games use it to create realistic graphics and movement. That fancy temple you saw in Hampi? Geometry and Trignometry. The design of the Taj Mahal? Geometry and Trignometry. Think the person designing knew sine, cosine, and tangent?

unnormalised: So, next time you see a triangle or a circle, don't run away screaming. Embrace the challenge and see what you can figure out. And remember: even if you mess up, you can always erase and try again. Just like life, hai na?

unnormalised: So, if someone throws a geometry or trig question at you, don’t just stare blankly. Give it a shot! And who knows, you might even find yourself enjoying it. At least, more than you enjoy doing the dishes, right? Now go forth and conquer those angles! Maybe use the tangent to calculate how fast you can get to the nearest vada pav stall. That's applied maths, right there.
